Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Situation2: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Story: I was walking home from school with my little brother, as always, keeping an eye out for him. We were almost at the corner store where I worked part-time as a cashier. My shift was about to start, so I told him to wait inside while I clocked in. Not long after, a woman came in, flustered, holding a blender she wanted to return. She didn’t have a receipt, and I knew the store’s policy was strict—no returns without proof of purchase. As I tried to explain this, she grew upset, her voice rising. Out of the corner of my eye, I saw my brother near the door, looking nervous and out of place. I felt torn—my manager expected me to enforce the rules, but my brother needed me to look out for him, especially in a busy store with strangers. My heart pounded as I tried to juggle the customer’s frustration and my brother’s anxious glances, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in on me at once.
